description: Full v3-7 normalized inventory: 345 base + 44 new model cards from IT Services, Securities, Real Estate, Management, and Healthcare deep dives. All 389 models sorted by composite, re-ranked.

SN.name: Structural Necessity
SN.description: Must this business exist given structural forces?

FA.name: Force Alignment
FA.description: How many F1-F6 forces drive it, weighted by velocity?

EC.name: External Context
EC.description: How much does international context materially change viability vs. US-only assessment?

categories.STRUCTURAL_WINNER: SN >= 8.0 AND FA >= 8.0 — must-exist business with multi-force convergence
categories.FORCE_RIDER: FA >= 7.0 — rides 3+ converging macro forces (and not STRUCTURAL_WINNER)
categories.TIMING_ARBITRAGE: TG >= 8.0 AND SN >= 6.0 — narrow entry window
categories.CAPITAL_MOAT: CE >= 8.0 AND SN >= 6.0 — cash-flow positive within 6 months
categories.FEAR_ECONOMY: Arises from fear friction: macro_source contains 'fear' or sector fear_friction_gap > 3
categories.EMERGING_CATEGORY: Doesn't map to existing NAICS or macro_source contains 'emerging'
categories.CONDITIONAL: Composite >= 60 but no other category matched (fallback)

notes: Models can have MULTIPLE categories assigned as a list
primary_category is the first matched in priority order
GEOGRAPHIC_PLAY removed — replaced by EC axis, no equivalent category
Batch normalization applied: v3-2_cycle (SN -1.5, FA -1.5, TG -2.5), new_macro_45 (SN -0.5, FA -0.3, TG -0.5)

models.name: AI Governance and Compliance Operating System
models.one_liner: Enterprise platform managing AI model inventory, risk assessment, bias monitoring, and regulatory compliance across US/EU/China regimes.
models.key_v3_context: The $86B fear economy (F5) has its most structured component in AI governance ($309M -> $15.8B = 51x). EU AI Act creates a HARD DEADLINE (Aug 2026) for compliance. Three diverging regulatory regimes (US, EU, China) make cross-jurisdictional compliance complex and valuable. This is fear-as-market-creator: the 46% adoption plateau and enterprise caution DRIVE demand for governance tools. v2 had one governance model (MC-52-003) in financial services only — this is the horizontal, cross-sector version.
models.macro_source: F5 Fear Economy + EU AI Act

CMMC is mandatory for defense contractors but not the broader economy — this prevents SN from reaching 9.0. Reassigned from STRUCTURAL_WINNER to FORCE_RIDER. This is the strongest FORCE_RIDER in the entire batch and would rank top 8 in the full 293-model inventory.

Five Eyes + NATO creates allied market. v2 missed this because it sits at the intersection of F1 (AI capability) and F3 (geopolitical acceleration) — no single NAICS sector captures it.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle

models.name: Securities Compliance Automation Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered SEC/FINRA compliance for broker-dealers and RIAs -- automate 80% of regulatory reporting at 5x lower cost than compliance staff. SEC 2026 exam priorities targeting AI use creates urgent demand.

structural_drivers: SEC 2026 exam priorities explicitly target AI in advisory -- every RIA must demonstrate AI compliance
SEC enforcing 'AI washing' under Section 206 anti-fraud provisions -- firms must prove AI claims
148K establishments in NAICS 523 need compliance infrastructure, fragmentation means most cannot build in-house
RIA M&A creates compliance complexity as merged firms harmonize regulatory obligations
Compliance staff costs $269K avg -- Baumol 3.71x makes dedicated compliance officers unaffordable for small firms

F1_technology.mechanism: AI parses regulations, auto-generates compliance reports, monitors trading violations, maintains audit trails. NLP/LLM makes regulatory text interpretation production-ready.

F3_geopolitics.mechanism: Cross-border regulatory divergence (US vs EU MiFID II vs UK FCA) creates multi-jurisdiction compliance automation demand.

F4_capital.mechanism: RIA consolidation creates compliance complexity. Fee compression makes compliance cost larger share of revenue -- automation preserves margins.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $20-80K/yr per firm (tiered by AUM and complexity)
unit_economics.cost_advantage: 5-8x vs dedicated compliance staff ($40K platform vs $200K+ compliance officer)

fear_friction.note: Fear of SEC AI examination DRIVES demand. Fear IS the sales trigger. Compliance is non-discretionary.

deep_dive_evidence.competitive_density: Legacy regtech (RegEd, ComplySci, COMPLY) serves larger firms. AI-native small-RIA focused: <5 entrants. Analogous to CMMC defense compliance (MC-DEF-011 scored 82.5).
deep_dive_evidence.TAM: 85K+ RIAs + 3,500 broker-dealers + 20K+ fund managers = 108K+ firms. At $40K avg ARR = $4.3B direct TAM. Jevons expansion to unserved micro-advisors = $6B+ total.
deep_dive_evidence.note: Highest composite in securities deep dive at 80.50 but SN 8.0 < 9.0 prevents STRUCTURAL_WINNER classification. Regulatory moat + counter-cyclical demand + highest CE. Also qualifies as TIMING_ARBITRAGE (TG 8.5 >= 8.5 and composite >= 65).

models.name: Micro-Firm AI Operating System
models.one_liner: All-in-one AI operating system for 1-5 person firms: AI employees handle ops, finance, legal, marketing, sales — human focuses on craft.
models.key_v3_context: This is the NUMBER ONE emerging category. 532K new businesses/month is Coasean shrinkage in action — transaction costs are falling, so firm size shrinks and firm count explodes. These micro-firms need everything a 50-person company has (accounting, legal, HR, marketing, sales) but cannot afford any of it at traditional prices. AI makes a 1-person firm operationally equivalent to a 10-person firm. v2 had MC-54-001 (micro-firm OS for professional services) — this is the HORIZONTAL version for ALL micro-firms, not just professional services. The v3 economy map shows Coasean shrinkage as a cross-sector pattern, not a professional services phenomenon.
models.macro_source: Coasean Shrinkage (532K/mo new businesses)

models.name: Healthcare AI Multi-State Compliance Platform

models.key_v3_context: This IS the fear economy: healthcare fear friction gap = 3, 34-pt trust gap, $86B fear economy TAM. Every regulation ADDS revenue. F3 acceleration (250+ bills, EU AI Act Aug 2026) is the primary driver. F5 psychology directly creates demand -- more fear = more compliance spending. SN high because regulatory complexity is structurally increasing (no political force reverses this). GG gets +2 for EU (AI Act creates parallel demand). TG strong but not top-tier: digital platform faces some Perez crash risk. CE good: subscription SaaS with low infrastructure cost.

models.name: Healthcare Revenue Cycle AI Automation
models.sector_name: Other Ambulatory Health Care Services (Revenue Cycle Management)

deep_dive_evidence.rcm_market: US healthcare RCM market: $250B+ (5-6% of $4.3T healthcare spend). Growing 12% CAGR as healthcare spending increases and payer complexity compounds.
deep_dive_evidence.coding_accuracy: AMA reports average medical coding accuracy of 63-65%. AI coding systems (3M, Fathom Health, Nym Health) demonstrate 88-95% accuracy in peer-reviewed studies. The accuracy gap = $125B+ in annual waste from denials, undercoding, and rework.
deep_dive_evidence.pe_distress_urgency: 30% of US hospitals PE-backed. Median PE healthcare deal leverage: 6.2x EBITDA. Rising interest rates + $930B refinancing wall = immediate cost-cutting pressure. RCM is the largest operational cost line item after labor.
deep_dive_evidence.change_healthcare_aftermath: Feb 2024 Change Healthcare cyberattack disrupted billing for 1/3 of US healthcare transactions. Health systems are actively diversifying RCM vendors — creating the largest market opening in a decade for new entrants.
deep_dive_evidence.competitive_note: Despite 10+ funded competitors, the market is $250B+ and highly fragmented. No single vendor has >15% market share. AI-native entrants target the 'mid-market gap' — too large for manual billing, too small for Optum enterprise contracts.

models.macro_source: Healthcare revenue cycle management is a $250B+ industry processing $4.3T in annual healthcare spending. Coding accuracy rates average 63-65% (AMA), creating $125B+ in annual waste from denials, rework, and undercoding. PE-backed systems entering distress need immediate margin improvement — RCM automation delivers 15-30% cost reduction with zero patient interaction. This is the Baumol cure entry point for healthcare: start with back-office (no trust barrier), prove ROI, expand to clinical adjacencies.

models.name: AI-Augmented RIA Rollup Platform
models.one_liner: Acquire retiring RIA practices at 5-8x earnings, consolidate onto AI-native platform, serve 3x clients per advisor at 40% lower cost. 85K establishments with 5.8 avg workers = most fragmented high-wage sub-sector in the economy.

structural_drivers: 38% of financial advisors plan to retire within a decade -- biological clock is non-negotiable
RIA M&A at record: 345 deals Q3 2025, $1.22T transacted, 440+ deals projected for full year
85,000 establishments averaging 5.8 workers -- extreme fragmentation invites platform consolidation
$68T intergenerational wealth transfer creates surging demand from digital-native heirs
Fee compression (83% of advisors <1% for $5M+ clients) makes sub-$200M standalone practices unviable

F2_demographics.mechanism: Silver Tsunami forces 38% of advisors toward exit. No replacement pipeline (entry-level hiring -24pp). $68T wealth transfer means demand surges as supply contracts.

F1_technology.mechanism: AI automates 60-80% of routine advisory work. Each advisor can serve 300-500 clients vs current 100-150. 5-person firm becomes 2-person AI-augmented team.

F4_capital.mechanism: PE validated model (75% of deals PE-backed) but adds overhead. AI-native rollup acquires at same multiples with lower operating cost. PE refinancing wall (2027-2028) opens secondary acquisition window.

unit_economics.cost_advantage: 2-3x vs traditional practice (AI reduces labor per client by 60%)
unit_economics.break_even: Each practice break-even at acquisition. Platform break-even at 20-30 practices.

fear_friction.note: RIA owners identify personally as 'trusted advisor.' Resolution: retain senior advisor 12-24mo, AI handles back-office, frame as capacity expansion not replacement.

deep_dive_evidence.competitive_density: PE consolidators at large-cap ($1B+ AUM). AI-native sub-$200M rollup: <5 funded entrants. Long tail of 50K+ sub-$200M practices underserved.
deep_dive_evidence.TAM: $50B acquirable revenue (50K+ sub-$200M practices x $1M avg). AI margin expansion = $10-15B. Jevons expansion to mass-affluent = $20-30B additional.

models.name: Investment Banking Junior Analyst AI Workforce System
models.one_liner: AI system replacing 60-70% of entry-level IB analyst tasks -- financial modeling, pitch decks, data rooms, due diligence at 90% cost reduction. Entry-level hiring already down 24pp.

structural_drivers: Entry-level finance hiring down 24 percentage points -- structural, not cyclical
Firms targeting 60-70% automation of junior analyst tasks within 12 months
PwC UK explicitly cut 200 entry-level roles citing generative AI
Cost of junior analyst ($100-150K all-in) vs AI system ($10-20K/yr) = 7-10x advantage
66% of enterprises reducing entry-level hiring due to AI (Stanford study)

F1_technology.mechanism: LLMs build financial models, generate comp analyses, draft pitch decks, parse data rooms, produce DD summaries. Structured rule-based tasks with clear outputs -- ideal for automation.

F2_demographics.mechanism: Entry-level pipeline destruction (-24pp decline, 67% junior dev collapse cross-sector) means firms cannot hire juniors even if they want to. AI fills supply gap.

F4_capital.mechanism: Fee compression in advisory puts pressure on deal execution costs. AI reduces cost per deal by 30-50%.

unit_economics.revenue_per_unit: $50-200K/yr per IB firm (tiered by deal volume and features)
unit_economics.cost_advantage: 7-10x vs junior analyst ($15K/yr system vs $100-150K/yr analyst all-in)
unit_economics.break_even: 50-100 mid-market IB firm subscriptions at $100K avg ARR

fear_friction.note: Zero friction at decision-maker level. Wall Street culture rewards performance. Firms ACTIVELY seeking to replace junior tasks. Fear exists only at entry-level being eliminated.

deep_dive_evidence.competitive_density: Bulge brackets building in-house (Goldman, JPM). Point solutions exist (AlphaSense, Kira). No integrated mid-market IB workflow platform. 2,000+ mid-market IB firms is addressable.
deep_dive_evidence.TAM: 2,000+ mid-market IB firms x $100K avg = $200M direct. Plus bulge bracket add-on: $100M. Plus PE/family offices: $200M. Total: $500M.

models.name: Acquire + Modernize CNC Shop (Single Site)

This is the archetype of a Perez turning-point-resilient business: revenue-generating, physical, cash flow positive. GG lower than rollup -- single-site is US-specific play.

Data compounding architecture provides crash resilience through recurring revenue. GG limited -- US-centric SMB play, replicable model in other markets but not directly transferable. models.name: AI Healthcare Staffing Command Center
models.sector_name: Home Health Care Services / Healthcare Staffing

deep_dive_evidence.bls_data: Healthcare added 82K jobs Jan 2026, 137K of 143K net = 95% of all job creation. Trailing 3mo: 54.1% of private sector hiring.
deep_dive_evidence.nursing_shortage: ANA projects 200K RN shortage through 2030. 40%+ currently considering leaving (National Nursing Workforce Survey). Average RN age 52 — retirement wave accelerating.
deep_dive_evidence.pe_distress: 30% of US hospitals PE-backed. $930B PE refinancing wall maturing 2026-2027. Agency nurse spend = largest controllable cost item for distressed systems.
deep_dive_evidence.travel_nurse_economics: Average travel nurse contract: $3,200-4,500/week (80-150% premium over staff RN). Top health systems spending $200-500M/year on travel nurses. AI demand prediction can reduce reliance by 30-50%.
deep_dive_evidence.fear_friction_note: Unlike patient-facing AI, staffing AI is WELCOMED by nurses. The fear vector runs the opposite direction: nurses fear the STATUS QUO (burnout, unsafe ratios) more than they fear the technology. This inverts the typical healthcare fear friction dynamic.

models.macro_source: P-039 Healthcare Employment Monoculture + 40%+ nurses considering leaving profession + 200K nursing shortage. Healthcare added 82K jobs in Jan 2026 (63% of all jobs) but cannot fill positions fast enough. Staffing is THE bottleneck: not whether healthcare hires, but whether it can physically find workers. Travel nurse agencies charge 80-150% markup during surges. AI demand prediction + credential matching + float pool optimization can collapse staffing transaction costs (T10 Coase) while keeping nurses in the profession longer through schedule optimization.

models.name: Private Credit AI Underwriting Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered underwriting and portfolio monitoring for private credit funds -- the dominant distress liquidity source as PE refinancing wall ($1.5-1.8T 2026-2028) forces credit restructuring at unprecedented scale.

structural_drivers: PE refinancing wall: $930B CRE + $1.5-1.8T total maturities 2026-2028 creates unprecedented distressed credit volume
Private credit has displaced banks as dominant non-bank lending source -- $1.7T+ AUM and growing
NAICS 52391 Miscellaneous Intermediation: extreme fragmentation (9,725 establishments, 0.284 fragmentation proxy)
Traditional credit underwriting requires 2-4 weeks per deal; AI compresses to 2-4 days for standard structures
Distressed asset evaluation requires rapid due diligence -- speed premium during refinancing wall

F1_technology.mechanism: AI parses financial statements, covenant packages, collateral documentation, and market comparables at 10x speed of human underwriters. NLP extracts risk signals from unstructured deal documents.

F4_capital.mechanism: PE refinancing wall creates $1.5-1.8T of maturity events requiring credit assessment. Private credit funds deploying $200B+/year need faster, more accurate underwriting to capture distressed opportunities.

deep_dive_evidence.invisible_pathway: Physicians are adopting AI without institutional knowledge or patient consent. Trust barrier is circumvented (physicians trust their own judgment, AI is a tool they consult) not overcome (patients still do not know or consent).
deep_dive_evidence.diagnostic_accuracy: Meta-analysis of 82 studies: AI diagnostic accuracy matches or exceeds human specialists in: radiology (AUC 0.94 vs 0.91 human), dermatology (AUC 0.91 vs 0.88), pathology (AUC 0.96 vs 0.93). Performance gap widens for rare conditions where AI training data exceeds individual physician experience.

models.macro_source: FDA deregulated AI clinical decision support (Jan 6, 2026) — removing the single largest regulatory barrier to physician-facing AI. 66% of physicians already using AI tools (invisible pathway: adoption happening without explicit trust transfer). The opportunity is in the physician-tool layer (high adoption, regulatory tailwind) NOT the patient-facing layer (trust barrier intact). Baumol destination sector dynamics (T4) mean physician time is the most expensive input in healthcare — AI that augments physician judgment has massive cost leverage.

The intermediary extraction is a T10 Coase transaction cost artifact: high information asymmetry (where are the shortages? which credentials match?) justifies agency fees. AI collapses the information asymmetry, enabling direct matching with transparent pricing. Both sides benefit: hospitals pay less, nurses earn more, agencies' margin is redistributed.

models.name: AI Patient Flow Optimization Engine

deep_dive_evidence.utilization_data: US hospital bed utilization: 65% average (AHA 2024). Wide variance: academic medical centers 80-85%, rural hospitals 35-45%, community hospitals 60-70%. The gap between perceived 'fullness' and actual utilization is a scheduling/throughput problem.
deep_dive_evidence.no_show_cost: No-show rates: 18-23% outpatient (meta-analysis of 105 studies). Annual cost: $150B+ in lost revenue, wasted capacity, and downstream care delays. AI prediction models achieve 85%+ AUC for no-show prediction (validated across multiple health systems).
deep_dive_evidence.competitive_landscape: LeanTaaS (iQueue): $175M raised, used by 1,100+ hospitals. Qventus: $95M raised, AI-powered operations. Both demonstrate market validation but neither has achieved dominant share. EHR vendors (Epic, Oracle) adding scheduling optimization modules.
deep_dive_evidence.capacity_math: US has ~920,000 staffed hospital beds at 65% utilization = 598,000 used daily. At 80% utilization = 736,000 used daily = 138,000 additional patient-days/day = equivalent of building 400+ new hospitals. AI scheduling is the infrastructure multiplier.

models.macro_source: P-039 monoculture means hospitals are adding 82K jobs/month but still cannot meet demand. The constraint is not just staffing — it is throughput. US hospital capacity utilization averages 65% despite 'full' perception. No-show rates average 18-23% across outpatient settings, costing $150B+ annually. AI scheduling (predictive no-show models, dynamic overbooking, automated reminders) and triage (acuity-based routing, ED-to-clinic diversion) can increase effective capacity 15-25% without capital expenditure. This is the capacity multiplier that healthcare's monoculture needs.

models.name: Healthcare Workforce AI Reskilling Academy

deep_dive_evidence.fear_signal: Fear friction gap (4) is among the highest in the economy. Healthcare workers score: economic readiness 8 (AI is here), psychological readiness 4 (not ready to adapt). This 4-point gap = demand for reskilling that bridges the psychological gap with structured competency.
deep_dive_evidence.retention_crisis: 40%+ nurses considering leaving profession (National Nursing Workforce Survey). Top reasons: burnout (48%), insufficient staffing (43%), work-life balance (38%), fear of changing role (22%). Reskilling addresses the 'fear of changing role' vector and partially addresses burnout (AI-augmented roles may reduce physical demands).
deep_dive_evidence.emerging_roles: New AI-augmented healthcare roles emerging: Remote Patient Monitoring (RPM) Coordinator, AI Clinical Workflow Manager, Telehealth Nurse Specialist, Precision Medicine Technician, AI-Assisted Triage Specialist. These roles command 10-25% salary premium over traditional bedside nursing.
deep_dive_evidence.institutional_gap: Only 12% of nursing schools include AI competency in curriculum (NLN survey). 0% of allied health certification programs include AI workflow training. Health systems spend $1,200-3,000/year per employee on continuing education but <5% is AI-related.

models.macro_source: P-039 monoculture + fear friction gap (4) + 40%+ nurses considering leaving = massive demand for healthcare workforce transformation. The monoculture pattern means healthcare cannot afford to lose workers — every nurse who leaves makes the shortage worse. AI reskilling offers a retention pathway: train existing workers for AI-augmented roles (AI-assisted triage, remote patient monitoring, clinical decision support operation) that are higher-value and lower-burnout than traditional bedside care. This is T25 Fear Economics: fear of displacement creates demand for reskilling, and the healthcare labor crisis makes that reskilling macro-critical.

models.name: AI-Native Trading Analytics Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered market intelligence and trading analytics at $5-10K/user vs Bloomberg $25K -- Jevons expansion from 325K terminals to 2M+ potential users. Conditional on overcoming Bloomberg moat.

structural_drivers: Bloomberg Terminal market ~$10B, with $2.1B at risk from AI-native alternatives
EU MiFID II 2026 updates enforce data accessibility -- weakens Bloomberg data exclusivity moat
Algorithmic trading market $23-33B growing at 12.9% CAGR creates AI-native analytics demand
AI trading platforms growing at 20% CAGR outpacing terminal-based workflows
Bloomberg's $25K/seat pricing reflects pre-AI data scarcity economics now being disrupted

F1_technology.mechanism: LLMs parse financial documents, synthesize market data, answer complex queries, generate reports at fraction of Bloomberg cost. Agentic AI executes multi-step research workflows.

F4_capital.mechanism: Fee compression in asset management makes $25K/seat terminal costs a target for cost-cutting.

F3_geopolitics.mechanism: EU MiFID II data accessibility mandate breaks Bloomberg data exclusivity moat. Regulatory tailwind for open data platforms.

fear_friction.note: Bloomberg workflow lock-in -- traders built careers around Terminal. 'Nobody gets fired for buying Bloomberg.' Resolution: target 2M underserved users who cannot afford $25K, complement then compete.

deep_dive_evidence.competitive_density: Bloomberg 33.4% market share with deep moat (network effects, data exclusivity, workflow lock-in). AlphaSense, Kensho/S&P emerging. Extremely difficult incumbent displacement.
deep_dive_evidence.TAM: 2M potential seats x $8K avg = $16B TAM (vs current $10B terminal market). Plus API/data layer = $5B. Total: $21B.
deep_dive_evidence.note: Lowest composite in securities portfolio at 66.00. Bloomberg moat, $15-50M capital, does NOT survive funding freeze. CONDITIONAL category -- viable only if Bloomberg fails to adapt AND sustained VC funding available. Largest Jevons multiplier (5-7x) if executed.

models.name: Rural Healthcare AI Lifeline Platform

deep_dive_evidence.closure_data: 136+ rural hospitals closed since 2010 (UNC Sheps Center). 2-3 closures per month ongoing. 46% of rural hospitals operating at a loss. 30% of remaining rural hospitals at high risk of closure (Chartis Center for Rural Health).
deep_dive_evidence.hpsa_data: 60M+ Americans in Health Professional Shortage Areas. 80% of rural counties are medically underserved. Average rural county has 0.4 specialists per 1,000 population (vs 2.1 in metros). The specialist gap is 5x.
deep_dive_evidence.cah_economics: 1,350 Critical Access Hospitals: 25-bed limit, cost-based Medicare reimbursement. Average operating margin: -2.4%. Average annual revenue: $25-45M. IT budget: $500K-1.5M (3-4% of revenue). AI platform must fit within $50-200K/year budget.
deep_dive_evidence.geographic_monoculture: Of the 82K healthcare jobs added in Jan 2026, an estimated 90%+ were in metropolitan statistical areas. Rural healthcare employment is flat or declining even as metro healthcare booms. The P-039 monoculture is a METRO monoculture — rural is excluded.
deep_dive_evidence.broadband_constraint: 25% of rural Americans lack broadband (>25Mbps). AI clinical decision support can run on lower bandwidth (3-5Mbps for text/data, 10+ for imaging). Edge computing models and offline-capable AI are required for rural deployment.

models.macro_source: P-039 healthcare monoculture concentrates job creation in metropolitan areas. Rural hospitals are closing at 2-3 per month (136+ closures since 2010). 60M Americans live in areas with physician shortages. Rural critical access hospitals (CAHs: 1,350 facilities) operate at 25-35% capacity utilization with $500K-2M annual losses. The geographic concentration of healthcare job creation is creating a two-tier health system: metro abundance vs rural desert. AI is the ONLY mechanism that can deliver specialist-level clinical capability to rural facilities without physically relocating physicians who refuse to leave metros.

TG moderate: digital, rate-dependent business. CE decent: SaaS operations model. CONDITIONAL on differentiation from large bank AI investments.

This is the meta-opportunity: using AI to predict AI's second-order effects on the economy. v2 could not see this because it analyzed sectors independently — the cascade only becomes visible when you map the connections between sectors.

models.name: AI-First Advertising Operations Service
models.one_liner: Full-service AI ad operations: campaign creation, optimization, reporting -- replacing traditional ad agencies at 5x lower cost
models.key_v3_context: baumol_cure + ai_inference_collapse both F1-heavy. Advertising is highly cyclical -- NOT crash resilient in late Perez. Convergence risk extreme: Google/Meta already automating ad ops. Platform dependence on Meta/Google ad APIs. Capital efficient but structurally weak necessity.

models.name: AI-First Design Agency (Full Service Replacement)
models.one_liner: Full-service AI design agency replacing traditional design firms at 5-10x lower cost -- 47,660 establishments, highest fragmentation in professional services
models.key_v3_context: Professional services EARLY_DISRUPTION applies but design is one of the MOST exposed to pure AI replacement (unlike accounting where trust/compliance matter). Only 1 force (F1 via baumol_cure + ai_inference_collapse). SN moderate: design services will always be needed but the race to the bottom on AI design pricing undermines the business model. FA weakest in portfolio: single force with no demographic, regulatory, or capital overlay. GG moderate: design is relatively global (visual output transcends language). TG weakest: pure-digital service in a commoditizing category at Perez turning point -- highest crash risk. CE excellent: near-zero marginal cost per project with AI. CONDITIONAL primarily on ability to maintain pricing power as AI design tools become ubiquitous.

models.name: Specialty Bakery Rollup (CA Focus)
models.one_liner: Consolidate CA specialty bakeries with shared AI production scheduling, FSMA compliance, and distribution network
models.key_v3_context: F1+F2. Rollup variant of bakery theme. CA-focused = very narrow geographic. Bakery rollup capital-intensive with perishable product logistics challenge. FSMA compliance moat is real but bakeries are small revenue units. Sub-variant of higher-ranked food models. Physical but highly local.

models.name: Securities Intermediation Intelligence (Data Compounding)
models.one_liner: AI for miscellaneous financial intermediation — loan brokers, transfer agents, financial planners. NAICS 523910+523999: 69K employees, 17K establishments, $230K+ avg pay. Start as AI-powered intermediation service, compound into financial flow intelligence. MODERATE density — less saturated than core wealth management.
models.key_v3_context: Data moat builds over time; vulnerable pre-scale. Sector phase: acceleration

models.name: AI-Augmented Real Estate Brokerage
models.one_liner: AI BENEFICIARY: Traditional real estate agents enhanced (not replaced) by AI: automated CMA generation, listing description writing, lead scoring, showing scheduling, contract review. NAICS 531210: 356K employees, 163K establishments. Agent stays for relationship/negotiation but AI handles 70% of research/admin. Agent productivity 2-3x higher = more deals per agent.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: AI Operations for Independent Grocery
models.one_liner: AI operations for independent grocery stores: demand forecasting, dynamic pricing, waste reduction, automated ordering, planogram optimization. NAICS 445110: 2.6M employees, $48K avg pay. Kroger/Walmart dominate but thousands of independent and ethnic grocers underserved by enterprise tech. Spoilage reduction alone can improve margins 2-3 percentage points.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: Child Care Licensing Compliance Platform
models.sector_name: Social Assistance - Child Day Care Services
models.one_liner: Multi-state child care licensing compliance: track requirements across 50 states, automate documentation, manage inspections
models.key_v3_context: regulatory_fragmentation=F3+F5 only. Narrow single-force family. Child care licensing is important but market small -- providers are small businesses with limited software budgets. US-only jurisdiction play. Capital efficient SaaS but tiny TAM per customer. Low SN -- compliance software, not structural necessity.

models.name: AI-Augmented Telehealth for Rural and Underserved Markets
AI Educational Support Services
models.one_liner: AI-powered educational support: tutoring, test prep, academic advising, learning disability screening. NAICS 611710: 204K employees. AI tutoring can be 24/7, personalized, and 10x cheaper than human tutoring ($15/hour AI vs $60-150/hour human). Khanmigo exists but limited. Jevons: every student gets personal tutor.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: AI-Augmented New Car Dealership Operations
models.one_liner: AI operations layer for car dealerships: lead scoring, inventory optimization, trade-in valuation, F&I product recommendation, service scheduling. NAICS 441110: 1.1M employees, 21K dealerships. EV transition creating massive retraining/retooling need. Dealerships are franchise-protected (state dealer laws) but operationally inefficient. CDK Global ($6B) shows platform market exists but is pre-AI.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: AI-Native Commercial Leasing Operations
models.one_liner: AI operations for nonresidential building lessors: tenant matching, lease optimization, maintenance scheduling, utility analysis, market comps. NAICS 531120: 157K employees, 27K establishments. Commercial real estate in turmoil (office vacancy 20%+, conversion to other uses). AI helps: adaptive reuse analysis, tenant credit scoring, operating cost optimization.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: AI Administrative Operations for Higher Education
models.one_liner: SUPPLY CHAIN: Universities (NAICS 611310, 1.26M employees) are downstream consumers of accounting, legal, IT, and administrative services. AI operations for universities: admissions processing, financial aid optimization, course scheduling, research administration, donor management. Workday/Ellucian are pre-AI ERP — gap for AI-native university operations.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: AI Operations for Multi-Site Outpatient Centers
models.one_liner: Full-service AI operations for outpatient care networks: scheduling, billing, prior auth, clinical documentation
models.key_v3_context: baumol_cure=F1+F2 only. Healthcare fear_friction_gap=3. Outpatient care growing (shift from inpatient). But athenahealth, eClinicalWorks dominate healthcare ops. Single force family. Crash partially resilient -- healthcare demand inelastic but elective procedures cyclical.

models.name: Independent Practice AI Services Marketplace
models.one_liner: Marketplace connecting independent healthcare practices with AI service providers (billing, scheduling, documentation, compliance)
models.key_v3_context: baumol_cure=F1+F2, coasean_shrinkage=F1+F4. Healthcare fear_friction_gap=3. Meta-marketplace (connecting practices with AI vendors) has chicken-and-egg problem. AI vendor landscape shifting rapidly. Independent practices already served by athenahealth marketplace. Low structural necessity for intermediary layer.

models.name: AI-Native Publishing Operations
models.one_liner: AI operations for periodical and niche publishers: content generation assistance, ad sales optimization, subscription analytics, audience segmentation. NAICS 513120+513199: 117K employees, 15K establishments, DECLINING employment. Baumol cure: editorial costs rising but AI can handle research, drafting, fact-checking. Full-service replaces 3-person editorial team.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: Human Premium Marketplace
models.one_liner: Verified marketplace for human-crafted services commanding 15-30% premium: artisan goods, hand-written content, human consultation, bespoke work.
models.key_v3_context: F5 psychology reveals a counter-current to AI adoption: 23% of people willing to pay 15-20% MORE for human services. This mirrors the organic food movement — a values-based market premium created by anxiety about the dominant mode of production. As AI content and services flood every market, the scarcity value of verifiably human work increases. This is a PURE EMERGING CATEGORY created by the AI transformation itself. No NAICS code exists for 'human-premium marketplace.' v2 could not detect it because it requires the F5 psychology framework.
models.macro_source: F5 Human Premium Signal (23% willing to pay 15-20% more)

models.name: Hospital Operations Intelligence (Data Compounding)
models.one_liner: Start with OR scheduling/patient flow optimization for independent hospitals, compound into definitive hospital operations benchmark database. Every hospital generates: procedure duration distributions, staffing ratios vs outcomes, supply utilization patterns. At 100 hospitals: predict optimal staffing levels. At 500: become the definitive hospital operations intelligence layer.
models.key_v3_context: Data moat builds over time; vulnerable pre-scale. Sector phase: early_disruption

models.name: AI Operations for Regional Airlines/Charter
models.one_liner: AI operations for regional/charter airlines: route optimization, crew scheduling, maintenance prediction, fuel optimization, revenue management. NAICS 481111+481211: 521K employees. Major airlines have AI teams but 200+ regional/charter operators lack capabilities. Each 1% fuel savings = $100K-1M/year per aircraft.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: Surface Treatment Services Rollup
models.one_liner: Consolidate coating/heat treating facilities with shared AI process optimization and scheduling
models.key_v3_context: F1+F2. Rollup variant of C7-AM-COATING-01. Environmental permits create moat. But rollup of surface treatment is capital-intensive and operationally complex. Niche sub-sector with limited scale potential. Physical assets provide floor.

models.name: AI Network Operations for Regional Telecoms
models.one_liner: AI network operations for wired/wireless telecoms. NAICS 517111+517810: 513K employees. AI handles: network optimization, predictive maintenance, customer churn prediction, capacity planning. AT&T/Verizon at enterprise but 1,300+ regional ISPs and CLECs underserved. 5G/fiber buildout creating new complexity.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: Elder Care Intelligence Platform (Data Compounding)
models.one_liner: Start with AI elder care coordination, compound into definitive aging population care intelligence. Every client generates: health trajectory patterns, medication interaction data, caregiver effectiveness metrics, cost-of-care benchmarks. At 10K clients: predict health crises before they happen. At 100K: become the definitive elder care data layer for insurers, hospitals, and policymakers.
models.key_v3_context: Data moat builds over time; vulnerable pre-scale. Sector phase: early_disruption

models.name: AI-Powered Micro-Firm Project Marketplace
models.one_liner: Marketplace connecting micro-firms (1-5 employees) for project collaboration, talent sharing, and capability assembly
models.key_v3_context: coasean_shrinkage=F1+F4, ai_inference_collapse=F1. Structural thesis (firms getting smaller) is sound but early. Upwork/Toptal/Fiverr dominate freelance marketplaces. Micro-firm collaboration is emerging category but unproven. Pure digital, NOT crash resilient. Capital efficient but low moat.

models.name: AI Operations for State/Local Government Services
models.one_liner: SUPPLY CHAIN: Government is the largest downstream consumer of professional services. As AI collapses those costs, government operations must also modernize. AI for state/local government: permit processing, constituent services, records management, budget analysis. 12-24 month procurement cycles but DOGE-driven modernization pressure creating urgency. Tyler Technologies ($1.8B) is incumbent but pre-AI.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: Acquire + Modernize Paper/Packaging Converter
models.one_liner: Acquire paper/packaging converting facility, deploy AI cutting optimization + robotic palletizing
models.key_v3_context: F1+F2. Paper/packaging converting is stable but low-growth. E-commerce packaging demand offsets paper decline. Physical + SBA 504. Commodity-adjacent margins challenge. Geographic tied to distribution logistics. Moderate crash resilience -- packaging demand tracks economic activity.

models.name: Acquire + Modernize Wood Products Facility
models.one_liner: Acquire specialty wood products manufacturer (millwork, trusses, prefab components), deploy AI optimization + robotic assembly
models.key_v3_context: F1+F2. Wood products tied to construction cycles -- NOT crash resilient. Housing starts sensitive to interest rates. Physical + SBA 504 eligible. Prefab components growing but commodity margins. Geographic limited to timber regions. Moderate structural necessity.

models.name: Acquire PE-Distressed Veterinary Practice
models.one_liner: Acquire PE-distressed veterinary practices at reduced multiples (PE paid 12-18x, available at 6-8x as PE exits), convert to AI-native operations with Digitail/Shepherd tools
models.key_v3_context: Time-limited arbitrage in veterinary PE distress. TG is the strength: PE exit window is real and time-bounded (2-3 years). But SN is limited (veterinary practice operation, not structural necessity), FA only 2 forces, and GG very low (US-specific). The arbitrage window thesis depends heavily on PE forced exits actually materializing in veterinary specifically -- less certain than in accounting or staffing where the distress signals are clearer. CE moderate: $1-3M per practice with physical assets. PARKED at 59.50 composite -- the timing arbitrage is real but the overall structural case is weak.

models.name: AI-Matched Contractor Marketplace
models.one_liner: AI-powered marketplace matching property owners with vetted building contractors, using job data for quality scoring
models.key_v3_context: F4 Coasean shrinkage + F2 Silver Tsunami (retiring contractors) create structural demand. But HomeAdvisor/Angi, Thumbtack, Houzz, and many others already compete heavily in this space. SN moderate: marketplace is helpful but contractors and homeowners already find each other through multiple channels. Only 2 forces with moderate intensity. GG low: local construction markets with jurisdiction-specific licensing. TG moderate: marketplace dynamics require critical mass, risky at Perez turning point without existing network. CE moderate: marketplace revenue model works at scale but reaching scale against incumbents is capital-intensive. PARKED because competitive landscape is extremely saturated.

models.name: Legal Intelligence Platform (Data Compounding)
models.one_liner: SMB legal service entry + compounding database of contract patterns, regulatory outcomes, and litigation data
models.key_v3_context: baumol_cure=F1+F2 only. Legal fear_friction_gap=5 (highest) -- adoption resistance is real barrier. Data compounding architecture strong long-term but 3-5yr moat build. Harvey AI ($715M), Casetext (acquired by Thomson Reuters) show VC interest but enterprise focus. SMB legal market fragmented but low willingness to pay.

models.name: AI Operations for Grantmaking Foundations
models.one_liner: AI for grantmaking organizations: grant application review, impact measurement, portfolio analysis, compliance monitoring. NAICS 813211: 77K employees, est. 12K foundations. Foundations review 10-50x more applications than they fund — AI can pre-screen and rank. Impact measurement still manual — AI enables continuous tracking.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: AI-First Wholesale Brokerage Service
models.one_liner: Replace wholesale trade brokers with AI matching + logistics optimization -- 122K establishments, employment declining
models.key_v3_context: coasean_shrinkage=F1+F4, ai_inference_collapse=F1. Wholesale pre_disruption phase. Employment declining validates structural shift. But Faire ($12.4B) and similar platforms already in market. Intermediary displacement is structurally sound but competitively crowded.

models.name: Property Operations Intelligence (Data Compounding)
models.one_liner: Start with AI property management for SMB landlords, compound into definitive rental market intelligence. Every property managed generates: maintenance patterns by building age/type, tenant payment behavior, seasonal demand, repair cost benchmarks. At 50K units: predict maintenance needs before failure. At 500K: become Zillow-level intelligence for operations.
models.key_v3_context: Data moat builds over time; vulnerable pre-scale

models.name: Full-Service AI Operations for Independent Dental Practices
models.one_liner: Full-service billing + scheduling + patient communication for independent dentists at 50% cost of in-house staff
models.key_v3_context: baumol_cure=F1+F2 only. Overlaps with C7-PI-DENTAL-01 (platform variant ranked higher). Dental ops replacement is sound but narrow. US-centric. Healthcare fear_friction_gap=3. Dentrix/Eaglesoft slow but entrenched. Single force family limits FA. Lower composite than platform variant.

models.name: Full-Service AI Creative Operations for Independent Artists
models.one_liner: AI operations layer for independent artists/writers/performers. NAICS 711510: 60K employees, 39K establishments = HIGHLY fragmented gig economy. AI handles: invoicing, contract review, IP management, royalty tracking, marketing. Jevons: at $49/month vs $5K/month traditional management, 10x more artists access professional operations.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: Tier 2/3 Auto Parts Supplier Rollup
models.one_liner: Consolidate small auto parts suppliers with shared AI quality systems and OEM compliance infrastructure
models.key_v3_context: F1+F2. Rollup variant of auto parts theme. OEM consolidation pressure on Tier 2/3 suppliers creates acquisition opportunity. But auto parts cyclical + EV transition uncertainty. Rollup is capital-intensive. Physical assets provide floor. Acquire+modernize variant (rank 41) is lower risk path.

models.name: AI Real Estate Transaction Intelligence
models.one_liner: SUPPLY CHAIN: Real estate agents/brokers (NAICS 531210, 356K employees, 163K establishments) consume legal, title, and inspection services upstream. As those costs fall, transaction costs fall — enabling more transactions. AI transaction platform: automated CMA, contract generation, title review, closing coordination. Jevons: lower transaction costs = more transactions.
models.key_v3_context: Data moat builds over time; vulnerable pre-scale

models.name: Hospitality Revenue Intelligence (Data Compounding)
models.one_liner: Start with AI revenue management for independent hotels, compound into definitive hospitality intelligence. Every property generates: pricing sensitivity curves, demand patterns, competitive set dynamics, seasonal coefficients. At 1K properties: predict citywide demand 30 days out. At 10K: become the STR of AI-native hospitality data.
models.key_v3_context: Data moat builds over time; vulnerable pre-scale

models.name: Specialty Food Producer Marketplace
models.one_liner: AI-powered marketplace connecting specialty food producers with retailers, restaurants, and distributors
models.key_v3_context: coasean_shrinkage=F1+F4, robotics_ai=F1. Food distribution already dominated by Sysco/USFoods at scale, Faire/RangeMe for specialty. Marketplace capital efficient but chicken-and-egg problem. Food is crash resilient but marketplace layer is not essential. Geographic limited by food logistics.

models.name: AI Lending Infrastructure Platform
models.one_liner: Platform infrastructure for surviving lenders: AI underwriting, servicing, compliance -- serving the survivors of the -9.8% employment decline
models.key_v3_context: baumol_cure=F1+F2, kondratieff_deployment loosely F1. Lending employment -9.8% validates disruption. But lending is highly cyclical -- NOT crash resilient in late Perez. Enclave/Blend/nCino well-funded competitors. Financial sector fear_friction_gap=1. Timing poor -- credit tightening reduces lending volume.

models.name: Freight Arrangement Intelligence (Data Compounding)
models.one_liner: AI freight brokerage starting as matching service, compounding into definitive freight intelligence. NAICS 488510: 271K employees, 24K establishments. WARNING: Convoy $900M failure at 100-1000x capital. Differential: don't try to be Uber-for-freight. Focus on specialized freight intelligence (cold chain, hazmat, oversized) where domain data creates moat.
models.key_v3_context: Data moat builds over time; vulnerable pre-scale. Elevated competitive density

models.name: Acquire Distressed Media/Publishing Properties
models.one_liner: Acquire distressed media properties (local news, trade publications, niche content) at 1-2x EBITDA, operate with AI-native cost structure. NAICS 512110+513120+513199: declining employment, massive PE write-downs. AI handles: content generation, ad sales, audience analysis. Revenue: existing subscriber base + AI-enabled content expansion. Vice, BuzzFeed bankruptcies prove distress; niche/local content still has value.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, arbitrage_window architecture

models.name: AI Agent Operations Platform for Service Businesses
models.one_liner: YC-INSPIRED: Every service business (law, accounting, consulting, real estate) needs AI agents but can't build them. Platform providing pre-built, compliant AI agents for specific service verticals. Different from Zapier/Make (workflow automation) — these are full agents that handle client communication, research, document preparation. Vertical-specific compliance built in.
models.key_v3_context: Sector phase: early_disruption

models.name: Acquire + Modernize Specialty Textile Mill
models.one_liner: Acquire specialty textile manufacturer (technical textiles, industrial fabrics) with AI loom optimization + robotic handling
models.key_v3_context: F1+F2. US textile manufacturing heavily offshored -- limited domestic opportunity. Technical textiles (industrial, military) niche defensible but small. Physical + SBA 504. Low geographic viability outside US/EU. Import competition structural headwind. Nearshoring trend (F3) provides some tailwind.

models.name: AI-Native Local News/Content Revival
models.one_liner: DEAD BUSINESS REVIVAL: Local newspapers/news sites are dying (2,900+ closures since 2005). Acquire at distressed pricing (1-2x revenue), operate with AI-native editorial + AI ad sales. Content generation cost drops 80%, ad targeting improves 3-5x. Local news has unique value (zoning, school boards, police reports) that AI-only content can't replicate. Combine local reporters + AI amplification.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, arbitrage_window architecture

models.name: Veterinary Clinical Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: Veterinary practice operations entry + compounding database of treatment outcomes, drug efficacy, and pricing benchmarks
models.key_v3_context: baumol_cure=F1+F2 only. Veterinary niche -- small TAM relative to human healthcare. Mars/JAB Holdings consolidating vet practices (Banfield, VCA). Data compounding sound but competing against corporate consolidation. Pet spending somewhat recession-resistant but discretionary at margin. US-centric.

models.name: Precision Agriculture AI Platform (Davis CA)
models.one_liner: AI platform for specialty crop operations: irrigation optimization, pest detection, harvest planning -- UC Davis ecosystem advantage
models.key_v3_context: robotics_ai=F1, kondratieff_deployment loosely F1. Effectively single force. AgTech heavily funded (John Deere, Climate Corp). UC Davis ecosystem is real but local advantage only. Agriculture less affected by silver tsunami in tech adoption. Geographic varies widely. Capital moderate for SaaS.

models.name: Craft Beverage Production Rollup
models.one_liner: Consolidate craft breweries/distilleries with shared AI production optimization and distribution network
models.key_v3_context: F1+F2. Craft beverage market saturating -- brewery count declining after peak. Rollup capital-intensive. Discretionary spending = NOT crash resilient. Brand fragmentation is feature of craft, not bug -- consolidation destroys value proposition. Distribution complexity. Physical assets provide floor but margins thin.

models.name: AI-Augmented Semiconductor Manufacturing Operations
models.one_liner: AI operations for semiconductor fabs: yield optimization, defect detection, process control, predictive maintenance. NAICS 334413: 204K employees, 2.4K establishments, $201K avg pay. CHIPS Act ($52B) creating massive new fab construction. Each fab spends $1B+/year on operations. AI yield improvement of 0.5% = $50-100M/year per fab.
models.key_v3_context: Sector phase: early_disruption

models.name: AI Energy Services for Electrification Transition
models.one_liner: SUPPLY CHAIN: Electrification (EV, heat pumps, solar) transforms both power distribution and power line construction. AI energy services: load analysis for EV charger placement, DER optimization, interconnection queue management, rate design analysis. Every utility needs this but internal teams understaffed. IRA incentives creating demand surge.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 1 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: AI Grid Operations for Electric Utilities
models.one_liner: AI operations platform for electric power distribution. NAICS 221122: 224K employees, $128K avg pay. Grid modernization (DER integration, EV charging, solar/storage) creating massive complexity that manual operations can't handle. AI handles: load forecasting, outage prediction, DER optimization, rate design. Regulated utility = slow but guaranteed adoption.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 1 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: Commercial Print Capacity Marketplace
models.one_liner: AI matching buyers with print capacity across 28K establishments -- fill idle capacity, reduce waste
models.key_v3_context: coasean_shrinkage=F1+F4, robotics_ai=F1. Print industry in secular decline. Marketplace for declining industry has shrinking TAM problem. Capital efficient but demand headwind. 28K establishments are consolidating/closing. Structural necessity low -- market needs FEWER printers, not better matching.

models.name: AI-Matched B2B Wholesale Marketplace
models.one_liner: Network marketplace connecting wholesale buyers directly to manufacturers/distributors via AI matching. Eliminates layers of intermediation. NAICS 425120 alone has 122K establishments of brokers/agents. At critical mass: network effects make individual brokers unable to match breadth of connections.
models.key_v3_context: Sector phase: pre_disruption

models.name: AI-Augmented Home/Building Inspection Service
models.one_liner: AI BENEFICIARY: AI-augmented building inspection: computer vision for defect detection, thermal imaging analysis, automated report generation, code compliance checking. Inspector still goes on-site but AI analyzes photos, generates report, flags issues. Throughput 3x (4 inspections/day vs 1-2). Price at 70% of traditional. Inspector licensing = moat.
models.key_v3_context: Sector phase: early_disruption

models.name: AI-Native Auto Parts Production Facility
models.one_liner: Greenfield AI-native auto parts production: automated machining + AI quality inspection + robotic assembly
models.key_v3_context: robotics_ai=F1 only. Single force. Greenfield = massive capital requirement vs acquire+modernize variant (rank 41). Auto parts OEM-dependent, cyclical. EV transition adds uncertainty to parts demand mix. Physical assets provide floor but greenfield payback is 3-5 years. Acquire path (rank 41) strictly dominates this.

models.name: AI-Native Craft Beverage Contract Production
models.one_liner: AI-optimized contract brewing/distilling for craft brands: fermentation monitoring, QC, packaging, distribution scheduling
models.key_v3_context: robotics_ai=F1 only. Single force = weak FA. Craft beverage market saturating (brewery count plateauing). Contract production already commoditized. Physical assets provide some crash resilience but discretionary demand hurts. Capital intensive greenfield. Narrow geographic play.

models.name: AI Construction Materials Distribution
models.one_liner: SUPPLY CHAIN: Infrastructure bill + construction modernization drives materials demand. AI materials distribution: demand forecasting from permit data, price optimization, logistics coordination, substitution recommendation. NAICS 423310+444180: 365K employees. Connects AI-modernized contractors to optimized supply chain.
models.key_v3_context: Sector phase: pre_disruption

models.name: AI-Native Print-on-Demand Production Facility
models.one_liner: Greenfield AI-native print-on-demand facility: automated prepress, AI personalization, robotic finishing -- $59.3B market by 2033
models.key_v3_context: robotics_ai=F1, ai_inference_collapse=F1. Both map to same force = effectively single force. Print industry secular decline. Greenfield = capital intensive with long payback. Shutterfly, Vistaprint dominate at scale. Physical assets provide some floor but print demand shrinking.

models.name: AI-Dispatched Motor Vehicle Towing Network
models.one_liner: AI dispatch marketplace for towing services. NAICS 488410: 74K employees, 11K establishments. Towing is hyper-local and fragmented. AI handles: automated dispatch (GPS-based closest truck), dynamic pricing, insurance/roadside integration. AAA dispatches 32M calls/year through manual dispatch. Honk/Swoop exist but neither dominant.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 2 forces, marketplace_network architecture

models.name: AI IT Equipment Lifecycle Management
models.one_liner: SUPPLY CHAIN: As businesses deploy more AI, IT equipment needs change dramatically (GPU servers, edge devices, networking). AI lifecycle management: procurement optimization, refresh planning, capacity forecasting, vendor negotiation. NAICS 423430: 235K employees, 18K establishments. CDW ($22B) is pre-AI procurement — gap for AI-native equipment lifecycle intelligence.
models.key_v3_context: Sector phase: pre_disruption

models.name: AI-Native Local Courier/Delivery Operations
models.one_liner: AI-native local courier/delivery: route optimization, demand prediction, dynamic pricing, fleet management. NAICS 492210: 177K employees, 9K establishments. Same-day delivery demand growing 20%+ annually. AI handles route optimization (30-40% fuel savings) + predictive demand staffing. Different from DoorDash (food) — B2B local delivery (medical samples, legal docs, parts).
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 1 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: AI-Enhanced Small Farm Operations
models.one_liner: AI BENEFICIARY: Small/specialty farms (not commodity row crop) enhanced by AI: pest/disease detection via phone camera, irrigation optimization, market price monitoring, harvest timing, regulatory compliance (organic/GAP). Davis CA location = direct access to UC Davis ag AI research and Central Valley growers. Jevons: AI makes precision agriculture accessible to 50-acre farms, not just 5000-acre operations.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 1 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: AI Operations Platform for Home/Elder Care Agencies
models.one_liner: SaaS+AI platform for 925K elder care agencies: caregiver scheduling, EVV compliance, care plan management, family portal, Medicaid billing. Current tools (ClearCare, Axxess) are pre-AI. Gap: AI-native platform that predicts staffing needs, automates compliance, and coordinates across providers.
models.key_v3_context: Sector phase: early_disruption

models.name: AI-Enhanced Agricultural Equipment Manufacturing
models.one_liner: Manufacture AI-enhanced farm equipment: autonomous implements, precision application systems -- AI builds the tools that modernize agriculture
models.key_v3_context: robotics_ai=F1, kondratieff_deployment loosely F1. Effectively single force. Competing against John Deere ($60B), AGCO, CNH Industrial. Equipment manufacturing is capital-intensive greenfield. Regulatory approval for autonomous farm equipment unclear. Physical but massive capital requirement. India +1 for agricultural modernization.

models.name: AI Supply Chain Platform for Modernized Manufacturers
models.one_liner: SUPPLY CHAIN: As manufacturing shops modernize (our top models), their supply chain must adapt. AI platform for industrial distributors: predictive reordering based on manufacturer production schedules, quality tracking across suppliers, just-in-time optimization. Connects upgraded manufacturers to upgraded suppliers.
models.key_v3_context: Sector phase: pre_disruption

models.name: AI-Native Travel Advisory Service Revival
models.one_liner: DEAD BUSINESS REVIVAL: Traditional travel agencies killed by Expedia/Booking. But complex travel (group, luxury, multi-destination, corporate) still needs human judgment. AI-native travel advisory: AI handles research/booking/logistics, human handles relationship/preferences/problem-solving. At $99/trip (vs $500+ traditional agent), Jevons: 5x more travelers use advisory services.
models.key_v3_context: Sector phase: acceleration

models.name: AI Analytics for Sports Teams/Organizations
models.one_liner: AI analytics for sports organizations: player performance prediction, injury prevention, fan engagement, ticket pricing, sponsorship valuation. NAICS 711211: 109K employees, 3.5K establishments, $266K avg pay. MLB/NFL/NBA at cutting edge but minor leagues, college sports, international leagues underserved. Jevons: AI analytics accessible to every high school team.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 1 forces, full_service_replacement architecture

models.name: AI Operations Platform for Landscaping Companies
models.one_liner: SaaS+AI platform for 122K landscaping companies: satellite property measurement, instant quoting, route optimization, crew management, invoicing. Current tools (Jobber, ServiceTitan) are generic field service — no landscaping-specific AI. At 5K users: predict seasonal demand, optimize equipment utilization across customers.
models.key_v3_context: Sector phase: acceleration

models.name: AI-Native Photo/Video Post-Production Service
models.one_liner: DEAD BUSINESS REVIVAL: Photo labs died with digital. But demand for professional post-production (color grading, retouching, compositing) surging with social media/e-commerce. AI handles 90% of post-production (auto color, background removal, upscaling). Full-service at $5-20/image vs $50-200 traditional. Jevons: every e-commerce seller gets professional product photos.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 1 forces, arbitrage_window architecture

models.name: AI Parts Intelligence for Auto Repair Modernization
models.one_liner: SUPPLY CHAIN: As auto repair shops modernize (our AM-AUTO models), parts procurement becomes data-rich. AI parts intelligence: predictive reordering, cross-reference optimization, counterfeit detection, pricing comparison. Every repair generates parts consumption data. At scale: predict parts demand by vehicle age/model/region weeks in advance.
models.key_v3_context: Data moat builds over time; vulnerable pre-scale. Sector phase: pre_disruption

models.name: AI Food Distribution Intelligence for Modernized Producers
models.one_liner: SUPPLY CHAIN: As specialty food producers modernize (our AM-FOOD models), distribution becomes the bottleneck. AI food distribution: demand forecasting, spoilage prediction, cold chain optimization, retailer matching. NAICS 424490+424410: 500K employees. Connects AI-modernized food producers to distributors to retailers. Data from production + distribution + retail = compound intelligence.
models.key_v3_context: Data moat builds over time; vulnerable pre-scale. Sector phase: pre_disruption

models.name: AI Warehouse Operations Platform
models.one_liner: AI operations platform for warehousing. NAICS 493110: 1.73M employees, 17K establishments. AI handles: inventory optimization, pick path optimization, demand forecasting, workforce scheduling. Robotics integration for automated picking. Amazon sets the bar but 17K independent warehouses lack these capabilities. $51K avg pay — massive labor cost to optimize.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 1 forces, platform_infrastructure architecture

models.name: Auto Repair Intelligence Platform (Data Compounding)
models.one_liner: Start as diagnostics service for independent shops, compound into definitive repair pattern database. Every vehicle serviced adds to diagnostic accuracy. At scale: predict failures before they happen, optimize parts inventory across network. Mitchell/AllData incumbents are static databases — AI-native system learns from every repair.
models.key_v3_context: Data moat builds over time; vulnerable pre-scale

models.name: Equipment Reliability Intelligence (Data Compounding)
models.one_liner: Start with AI-augmented equipment repair, compound into definitive equipment failure pattern database. Every repair generates: failure mode, time-to-failure, parts consumed, environmental conditions. At 100K repairs: predict failures weeks before they happen. At 1M: become the predictive maintenance intelligence layer for industrial equipment.
models.key_v3_context: Data moat builds over time; vulnerable pre-scale

models.name: AI Operations Platform for Beauty/Salon Industry
models.one_liner: Platform for beauty/salon industry: AI booking, client preference learning, inventory optimization, social media content generation. Fresha, Vagaro exist but limited AI. Gap: AI-native platform that actually generates social content and predicts trends.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 1 forces, platform_infrastructure architecture

models.name: AI Operations Platform for Property Managers
models.one_liner: Platform for 98K property management companies: AI tenant screening, predictive maintenance, automated rent collection, compliance tracking. AppFolio ($7B) validates market but limited AI. Gap: AI-native platform purpose-built for SMB managers (5-50 units).
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 1 forces, platform_infrastructure architecture

models.name: AI Operations Platform for Self-Storage
models.one_liner: AI operations for self-storage facilities: dynamic pricing, demand forecasting, automated move-in/move-out, security monitoring, marketing optimization. NAICS 531130: 59K employees, 18K establishments. Public Storage/Extra Space dominate REITs but thousands of independent operators. Storeganise and similar exist but pre-AI.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 1 forces, platform_infrastructure architecture

models.name: AI Platform for Furniture/Home Furnishings Retail
models.one_liner: AI for furniture/home retailers: AR room visualization, inventory optimization, customer preference learning, delivery route optimization. NAICS 449210: 415K employees, est. 30K establishments. Wayfair ($12B) at online but physical furniture retail (70% of sales) still analog. AI bridges online visualization with in-store experience.
models.key_v3_context: Expansion model, 1 forces, platform_infrastructure architecture

models.name: Specialized Freight Intelligence (Post-Convoy Lesson)
models.one_liner: FAILURE STUDY: Convoy ($900M failure) tried to be Uber-for-freight in general trucking — marketplace without differentiation. Lesson: general freight matching is commoditized. Opportunity: SPECIALIZED freight intelligence (cold chain, hazmat, oversized, high-value) where domain expertise creates data moat. Focus on 1-2 specialized segments, not general marketplace.
models.key_v3_context: Data moat builds over time; vulnerable pre-scale

models.name: Platform Government AI
models.one_liner: Platform for government AI -- 12-24mo procurement, Tyler Tech $1.8B
models.key_v3_context: regulatory_fragmentation=F3+F5 loosely. Tyler Technologies ($1.8B) dominates govtech. 12-24 month procurement cycles = terrible capital efficiency. Government AI adoption extremely slow. DOGE/efficiency efforts could accelerate but unpredictable. Not crash resilient -- government budgets cut in downturns.

models.name: Vertical SaaS Therapist Notes
models.one_liner: Vertical SaaS for therapist clinical notes -- Blueprint 50K clinicians, tool-layer commodity
models.key_v3_context: baumol_cure=F1 only. Blueprint dominates with 50K clinicians. Tool-layer commodity with no data compounding or regulatory moat. Pure digital, not crash resilient. Healthcare fear_friction_gap=3 but market already captured. No structural necessity -- incumbents serve this.

models.name: Vertical SaaS Shopify Bookkeeping
models.one_liner: Vertical SaaS for Shopify bookkeeping -- Finaloop $35M direct competitor
models.key_v3_context: baumol_cure=F1 only. Finaloop ($35M) is direct competitor in Shopify bookkeeping. Platform dependence on Shopify API. Shopify itself could add bookkeeping features. Tool-layer commodity. Narrow niche within already-served market. Capital efficient but no structural moat.

models.name: Vertical SaaS AG Irrigation
models.one_liner: Vertical SaaS for AG irrigation -- Orchard Robotics $22M, OEM risk
models.key_v3_context: robotics_ai=F1 only. Orchard Robotics ($22M) is direct competitor. OEM integration risk (John Deere, Trimble control distribution). AgTech has long sales cycles (annual planting). Water scarcity creates need but market fragmented and low-tech adoption. Not crash resilient -- ag commodity prices volatile.

models.name: Vertical SaaS Clinical Documentation
models.one_liner: Vertical SaaS for clinical documentation -- Abridge $250M captured, tool-layer commodity
models.key_v3_context: baumol_cure=F1. Abridge ($250M funding) has captured clinical documentation AI. Microsoft/Nuance DAX also dominant. Tool-layer commodity. No structural moat for new entrant. Healthcare fear_friction_gap=3 but market already served. Timing terrible.

models.name: Vertical SaaS Payroll+Bookkeeping
models.one_liner: Vertical SaaS for payroll + bookkeeping -- Gusto $746M, Rippling $1.3B too dominant
models.key_v3_context: baumol_cure=F1 only. Gusto ($746M) and Rippling ($1.3B) have captured this market. Tool-layer SaaS against well-funded incumbents. No structural moat. Timing terrible -- market locked up. Pure digital commodity.

models.name: Vertical SaaS Auto Claims Photo
models.one_liner: Vertical SaaS for auto claims photo AI -- Tractable $115M, CCC public
models.key_v3_context: robotics_ai=F1 only. Tractable ($115M) and CCC (public company) dominate. Photo-based claims estimation is commoditizing. Insurance carrier switching costs benefit incumbents. No structural gap for new entrant. Financial sector fear_friction_gap=1 but irrelevant -- market captured.

models.name: Consumer Mental Health App
models.one_liner: Consumer mental health app -- saturated: Calm, Headspace, BetterHelp
models.key_v3_context: Minimal force alignment. Saturated market with well-funded incumbents (Calm, Headspace, BetterHelp). Consumer app = high CAC, low retention. NOT crash resilient -- discretionary wellness spend. No regulatory moat. No data compounding unique to entrant. Market over-served.

models.name: AI Crypto/DeFi Analytics
models.one_liner: AI crypto/DeFi analytics -- regulatory uncertainty, many funded competitors
models.key_v3_context: No meaningful force alignment beyond F1 loosely. Crypto is speculative, not structural economic force. Chainalysis, Nansen, Dune well-funded. Regulatory uncertainty in US (F3 negative). NOT crash resilient -- crypto correlates with risk-on sentiment. No demographic or geographic structural driver.

models.name: Vertical SaaS Real Estate AI
models.one_liner: Vertical SaaS for real estate AI -- $10.5B funding, 7 unicorns
models.key_v3_context: Minimal force alignment. $10.5B already deployed by 7 unicorns. Most over-funded vertical in proptech. No structural gap. Timing worst possible. Real estate cyclical. Tool-layer commodity against massive incumbents.

models.name: AI Code Generation Tool
models.one_liner: AI code generation tool -- GitHub Copilot, Cursor, Windsurf platform commoditization
models.key_v3_context: Zero structural necessity for new entrant. GitHub Copilot (Microsoft), Cursor, Windsurf, Claude Code already dominant. Platform companies (GitHub, JetBrains) integrating AI natively. No moat possible against platform-integrated tools. Timing worst possible.

models.name: General AI Writing Tool
models.one_liner: General AI writing tool -- ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini free tier commoditized
models.key_v3_context: Zero structural necessity. ChatGPT/Claude/Gemini provide writing capability at free tier. Platform commoditization is complete. No moat possible. Timing worst possible -- foundation model providers own this. Geographic irrelevant (global competition). AI writing is the textbook commoditized tool layer.
